Last unit does not have enough valid bits

The "Last unit does not have enough valid bits" error occurs in Java when you try to convert a BigInteger value to a long primitive type, but the BigInteger value is too large to fit into a long.
A long in Java is 64 bits, with 1 bit for the sign and 63 bits for the value. So the maximum possible value is 2^63 - 1.
If the BigInteger value exceeds this range, then converting it to a long will cause the "Last unit does not have enough valid bits" error.
For example:
```java BigInteger big = new BigInteger("9223372036854775808");
long longValue = big.longValue(); // Error! ```
Here the BigInteger value is 2^63, which is 1 larger than the max long value.
To fix this, you have a few options:
1. Check if the BigInteger is in the long range before converting:
```java if(big.compareTo(BigInteger.valueOf(Long.MAX_VALUE)) <= 0) { longValue = big.longValue(); } ```
2. Convert to a different type like BigDecimal or String instead of long.
3. Use methods like longValueExact() which will throw an ArithmeticException on overflow.
4. Handle the ArithmeticException from longValue() to deal with overflow.
So in summary, the error occurs when converting a too-large BigInteger to long. Check the range, use a different type, or handle potential exceptions to prevent it.

base64 Last unit does not have enough valid bits

The "Last unit does not have enough valid bits" error can occur when decoding a Base64 encoded string in Java.
This is caused by the length of the encoded string not being a multiple of 4, which means the decoder does not have a full valid block of Base64 characters to decode.
For example:
```java String encoded = "SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ"; // Length 15
byte[] decoded = Base64.getDecoder().decode(encoded); // Error ```
Here the encoded string has a length of 15 characters, which is not a multiple of 4.
To fix this, you need to pad the encoded string with '=' characters to make it a multiple of 4 before decoding:
```java String encoded = "SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ="; // Length 16
byte[] decoded = Base64.getDecoder().decode(encoded); // OK ```
The '=' padding character tells the decoder to ignore any missing bytes in the last block.
Alternatively, you can use Base64.getDecoder().decodeChunked() which does not require padding:
```java byte[] decoded = Base64.getDecoder().decodeChunked(encoded); // OK ```
So in summary:
- Base64 strings should have a length multiple of 4 - Add '=' padding characters if needed - Use decodeChunked() for unpadded strings - Otherwise you may get "Last unit does not have enough valid bits"

com.openhtmltopdf.util.XRRuntimeException: Can't load the XML resource

The "Can't load the XML resource" exception in openhtmltopdf occurs when it fails to load the built-in res/xml/css-parsing-spec.xml file which contains the CSS parsing rules.
This typically happens if the xml file is missing from the classpath or jar file.
Some ways to resolve it:
- Make sure openhtmltopdf-*.jar is in the classpath and css-parsing-spec.xml exists inside under res/xml/
- If using Maven, check the dependency has a classifier of 'fontbox-all' which contains the XML file
- Try redownloading the JAR file in case it got corrupted
- Explicitly extract css-parsing-spec.xml from the jar and load it:
```java InputStream spec = MyClass.class.getResourceAsStream("/res/xml/css-parsing-spec.xml"); builder.useCSS(new DiskCachedCSSResolver(spec)); ```
- As a workaround, disable CSS parsing completely:
```java builder.useCSS(new NoCSSResolver()); ```
So in summary, this error occurs due to a missing XML resource file. Verify the JAR contains it under res/xml/, check classpath dependencies, redownload the JAR, extract it manually, or disable CSS as workarounds.
